posts.cooked: Is there a way to create a slew rate limiter that only takes effect when decreasing the overall magnitude of an input? We would like to make a limiter such that it makes the slowdown of our robot from top speed takes longer, while not impacting the initial acceleration of the robot, which we cycle with driving both forwards and backwards. Thanks!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You can pretty easily modify the implementation of the existing SlewRateLimiter to do this; but why?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
How would you modify the implementation of the existing SlewRateLimiter? My first guess from looking at the documentation is that the forward and reverse just effect when going forward and backwards, so checking whether the controller input is positive or negative, and then only setting one of the limits based on that could possibly work? Although that most likely wouldn’t fix it if our driver releases the joystick entirely.

As to why we would like to do this, our driver doesn’t want us to mess with acceleration time, but right now, our robot likes to tip when stopping from full speed:

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
iz_en_zi:

How would you modify the implementation of the existing SlewRateLimiter?

Before applying the limit, check which direction the change of magnitude is in.  I’m still not sure this is a great idea though:

If your robot tips when stopping from full speed, it’ll also tip when starting from a dead stop.  The two are kinematically identical.  You might have different tippiness in the forward/backward direction, but not when speeding up c.f. slowing down.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

it’ll also tip when starting from a dead stop

We have a shifting drivetrain, so when accelerating we usually start in a lower gear before shifting to our high gear. From what I’ve been told, the reason we don’t shift down before fully decelerating is that because there is a slight delay between operator input and the robot shifting (about 1s), and because we are driving around 18ft/s, the precision of timing needed to shift down is too much. The other option would be to only apply the limit when the robot is in high gear possibly?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
iz_en_zi:

The other option would be to only apply the limit when the robot is in high gear possibly?

This seems like a better option.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: Would it be better to configure this in the subsystem or the command for the driving? From the example code I’ve seen the limiters are usually configured in the commands for driving, but our variable for what gear we are in is stored in our drive subsystem. Would it work better to set the limiter in our ArcadeDrive function rather than our ArcadeDrive command?

posts.name: Bharat Khadka
posts.cooked: We have this same issue with our swerve, our acceleration is fine but when the robot comes to a sudden stop it tips, most likely due to inertia. Would implementing a SlewRateLimiter only for negative joystick values help the tipping or should we put a limiter for positive and negative input? Also, should the limiter be implemented when setting Teleop Swerve or when we bind joystick input to the drive?

Limiting negative joystick values only wouldn’t help, as that would only change how fast you ramp down when going forward, and going negative would only decrease your acceleration. What you are looking for is limiting it as the magnitude of the value gets closer to 0.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

If your robot tips when stopping from full speed, it’ll also tip when starting from a dead stop.

Not necessarily. The accelerations in those two cases are different.

For others reading, acceleration is what we care about here because unbalanced torques tip the robot, torque = r x F, and F = ma where r is the “lever-arm” vector, F is the force vector, m is mass, and a is acceleration. I’m going to hand-wave this because I just tried doing the free body diagrams, and it was taking too long. Basically, you have a wheel torque around the center of mass (ignoring wheel friction which is what actually causes the wheels to do anything), a gravity force at the center of mass, and a normal force at the wheel contact patch, which moves if the robot rocks backwards.

tl;dr of this post is that deceleration magnitude from max speed is twice as high as acceleration magnitude from rest, and of the various options for acceleration limiting, voltage slew rate limit is the worst and closed-loop acceleration limit is the best (WPILib has the DifferentialDriveAccelerationLimiter class for that purpose).

Consider the acceleration model \dot{x} = Ax + Bu where \dot{x} is acceleration, x is velocity, u is voltage, A = -\frac{K_v}{K_a} , and B = \frac{1}{K_a} . (It’s a state-space model created from SysId constants.)

When accelerating from rest, x = 0 m/s and u = u_{max} .

\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= \left(-\frac{K_v}{K_a}\right)(0) + \left(\frac{1}{K_a}\right)(u_{max}) \\
\dot{x} &= \frac{u_{max}}{K_a}
\end{align*}

Since we’ll need it later, the max steady-state velocity for this model is:

\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= -\frac{K_v}{K_a}x_{max} + \frac{1}{K_a}u_{max} \\
(0) &= -\frac{K_v}{K_a}x_{max} + \frac{1}{K_a}u_{max} \\
\frac{K_v}{K_a}x_{max} &= \frac{u_{max}}{K_a} \\
x_{max} &= \frac{u_{max}}{K_v}
\end{align*}

When decelerating from max speed, x = \frac{u_{max}}{K_v} and u = 0 .

\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= \left(-\frac{K_v}{K_a}\right)\left(\frac{u_{max}}{K_v}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{K_a}\right)(0) \\
\dot{x} &= -\frac{u_{max}}{K_a}
\end{align*}

When decelerating from max speed, x = \frac{u_{max}}{K_v} and u = -u_{max} .

\begin{align*}
\dot{x} &= \left(-\frac{K_v}{K_a}\right)\left(\frac{u_{max}}{K_v}\right) + \left(\frac{1}{K_a}\right)(-u_{max}) \\
\dot{x} &= -\frac{u_{max}}{K_a} - \frac{u_{max}}{K_a} \\
\dot{x} &= -\frac{2u_{max}}{K_a}
\end{align*}

The acceleration in case 3 is twice as high as in case 1. I suggest limiting the acceleration in both directions to be \left(-\frac{u_{max}}{K_a}, \frac{u_{max}}{K_a}\right) so you don’t tip over when applying max positive voltage when driving full speed backward.

Here’s a demonstration of different acceleration limiting methods:

diff_drive_acceleration_limit_methods 1920×526 104 KB

diff_drive_acceleration_limit_methods 1920×526 104 KB

diff_drive_acceleration_limit_methods 1920×526 104 KB

and here’s the script that generated the plots:

The voltage slew rate limit exponentially converges to an acceleration limit, but not the desired one. Reducing the slew rate limit further to keep the max acceleration below the desired max will degrade performance.

An implicit model follower is a feedback controller that makes the drivetrain behave like one with tamer dynamics. I’ve used it as training wheels for drivers before.

It’s nice for getting a natural drivetrain response, but it still doesn’t achieve acceleration limiting directly. While it does obey the acceleration limit, it’s still leaving performance on the table.

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.math.controller, class: ImplicitModelFollower

The acceleration limiter applies the maximum voltage it can while still obeying the acceleration limit.

declaration: package: edu.wpi.first.math.controller, class: DifferentialDriveAccelerationLimiter
